block.p: Amy Jean Mayer, an assistant New York State attorney general, is to be married today to Daniel Franklin Oscar, the founder and president of the Learning Project, an alternative schools organization. The Rev. Dorothy Dai-en Friedman, a Buddhist priest, will perform the nondenominational ceremony at the Picnic House in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Associate Justice Gary S. Stein of the New Jersey Supreme Court, for whom the bride was a law clerk, is to take part in the ceremony.
The bride, 34, and bridegroom, 33, graduated from Princeton University, she magna cum laude and he cum laude.

Amy Jean Mayer, an assistant New York State attorney general, is to be married today to Daniel Franklin Oscar, the founder and president of the Learning Project, an alternative schools organization. The Rev. Dorothy Dai-en Friedman, a Buddhist priest, will perform the nondenominational ceremony at the Picnic House in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Associate Justice Gary S. Stein of the New Jersey Supreme Court, for whom the bride was a law clerk, is to take part in the ceremony.
The bride, 34, and bridegroom, 33, graduated from Princeton University, she magna cum laude and he cum laude.

Ms. Mayer, who is keeping her name, works in the Bureau of Consumer Frauds and Protection in Manhattan. She received a master's degree in East Asian languages from the University of Chicago and a law degree cum laude from Harvard. Her parents, Anne D. Mayer and Dr. David L. Mayer, live in Princeton, where the bride's father has a private psychoanalytic practice. He is also a clinical professor of psychiatry at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in Piscataway, N.J. Her mother, a retired research psychobiologist, worked in Newark at the Institute of Animal Behavior of Rutgers University; she is now a volunteer carpenter for the Trenton chapter of Habitat for Humanity, an organization that builds housing for the homeless.

Mr. Oscar's organization, which is based in Manhattan, established the John A. Reisenbach Charter School in Harlem, and TLP One Middle School, an alternative school for neighborhood children on the Lower East Side. He is the son of Sue E. Oscar and Gerald M. Oscar of Manhattan. The bridegroom's mother is a president of Filmakers Library, a distributor of documentary films. His father retired from Nynex, for which he was the general solicitor, representing the company in legal disputes involving rate increases and other matters.
